hedline.hl1: MICROVISION UNIT TO HANDLE NEW SWITCHES

abstract.p: Microvision, developer of display and scanning devices, transfers its effort to develop organic optical switches and light processing materials to new subsidiary named Lumera (S)

block.p: Microvision, a developer of display and scanning devices, has transferred its effort to develop organic optical switches and light processing materials to a new subsidiary named Lumera. Microvision, based in Bothell, Wash., said Lumera will shortly complete a $25 million to $30 million private round of fund-raising. Lumera's technology, based on research at the University of Washington first made public in April, relies on light-sensitive organic molecules embedded in plastic instead of metallic crystals to convert light into electrical signals. The novel materials reportedly combine extremely high switching speeds with low power requirements.
